This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

After a disappointing bid for the Presidency, Hickenlooper has the name recognition and support to win this seat. He has been up big in recent polling and is unlikely to drop that lead anytime soon given Gardners low popularity in the state and the regions recent blue tilt at the federal level.

I like both candidates.  This is rare because I dislike most politicians.   Interesting race though because neither has ever lost an election.  Correct me if I'm wrong.   Lickenhooper, um I mean Hickenlooper is liked by many including independents and some on the right.  He won governor election back when Colorado was still a bit red or purple anyway.
No way do Republicans keep this seat
Maybe overconfident, but the Dem has consistently lead with a 8-10 point lead, and Biden is running strong in CO.
The republican attacks on Hickenlooper just don’t seem to be getting any traction
Updating to reflect Hickenlooper's dominance in the polls as well as a double digit lead for Biden in the state, which is likely to affect down-ballot races substantially.

Last poll from late July puts Hickenlooper up at only 6-points [1]. Gardener has about twice the money, but Hickenlooper has been spending like made in the last quarter [2]. Though Gardner is the incumbent, his opponent was a Democratic presidential contender and has a large amount of name recognition as well as a sizable lead. However, Gardner has picked up some steam in the past month and has a small chance of making up the difference if he continues his upward momentum.
It doesn’t appear Hickenlooper’s ethics problems will be much of a problem for voters.

Former Governor John Hickenlooper has a double-digit lead in the polls. [1] The latest poll by Public Policy is partisan but largely reflects Hickenlooper's lead throughout the campaign so far. [1] https://endcitizensunited.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/ColoradoResults1.pdf
I feel weird being confident this far out but this is what my model says! I can always adjust down.

Hickenlooper is ahead and will win.
Hickenlooper consistently leading with double digits.
Change: Dems (-5) Reasoning: Hickenlooper has looked better.
Dialing back to the crowd forecast until at least after results come out from Tuesday’s primary.
Split-ticket voting is rare these days and Colorado is pretty blue these days, and Hickenlooper is even more popular than a generic Democrat in Colorado.
Regardless of who ends up on the democrat ticket, this should be an easy win.
Hickenlooper has really stumbled lately in the primary and has had a lot of bad press. It will still be tough for Gardner to win but this helps him.

-Hickenlooper is a popular/centrist former governor and Denver mayor in a Dem-leaning state. He was 18 points ahead of Gardner in a May 6th poll. And Biden is polling at +13%, +18%, and +19% ahead of Trump in Colorado in three polls that came out in May.
Hickenlooper is a popular former Governor, and sentiment against Trump carries the day.
Hickenlooper‘s gubernatorial success, incumbent Gardner’s tardy and ineffectual development of a spine
Biden is +15 on average and Hickenlooper is +17. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/colorado/
Gardner is too tied to Trump and Trump is not likely to do well in a state that Clinton won and continues to become more and more blue.
While Colorado has been trending Democrat, I believe the recent charges against Hickenlooper will cause them to remain in the Republican camp, choosing a lesser of two evils.
Hickenlooper has a long track in Colorado which has been generally positive.  General dismay with any current member of Congress supports a new candidate.
Colorado is definitely going blue. Gardener is extremely unpopular.
Corey Gardner can start cleaning out his desk because he is going to lose by somewhere between fifteen and twenty points on election day
Colorado is a blue state but weird

Change: Dem (+3) GOP (-3) The MJ industry is afraid of endorsing Gardner cause they think he's going to lose.
Colorado's demographics, and the Presidential unpopularity do not bode well for Gardner, though raw polling up to this point have not had an opponent so that could change.
Backing down a bit, 75 seems a bit overconfident. There is still uncertainty about the nominee for D and there will be debates where stuff can change fast

CO trending blue since 2014. Hickenlooper has double digit lead in polls, though not many polls yet. Gardner favorability declining in recent polls. However, Gardner has slight edge in fundraising. Calling this a toss-up, slight lean toward Dem for now.

Two polls on 538 show Hickenlooper with a considerable lead, at +17 and +18 over Gardner [1]. Gardner, though, still has a cash advantage [2]. Moving to a slight edge for D. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/colorado/
[2] https://www.vox.com/2020/5/18/21243174/most-competitive-senate-races-2020

Colorado is trending deep blue, and its Democratic governor has walked between the raindrops in charting a course through COVID, not becoming a target of extremist ire from either side.   There are states where a high turnout of Trump voters could save the GOP Senate candidate but CO is not one.
Hickenlooper popular former governor,  Gardner not popular, Colorado blue
John Hickenlooper is still very popular in Colorado. Cory Gardner won by 3% in 2014 and incumbent Senators have not done very well in Colorado going back to the 1990s.
this election will be a blood bath against whoever is in office

Colorado is a blue state and increasingly so, with so few senate races going the other way to the Presidential race in election years that's already a good start for Hickenlooper. Add to that his polling and fundraising lead, and his prominence in the state as former governor, and he is strong favourite. Maybe even more than 80%.

I am from Colorado and quite familiar with state politics. Cory Gardener is deeply unpopular in Colorado and not just with Democrats. He is not a favorite of Republicans in general, seen as being too milquetoast, inauthentic. Additionally Republicans in the state are politically dejected as they have watched Colorado become what is essentially a blue state.  I believe most Republicans in the state and nation assume Gardener will lose his seat. There will be little zeal, even within Colorado, for Gardener's reelection I believe; which will translate broadly to comparatively light campaign contributions, from small donors, PACS or even the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, even though Gardener was chair as recently as 2019. Democrats on the other hand are eagerly looking at Gardener's seat. I believe the DNC likely assume they will pick the seat up in 2020, which is one of three potential wildcards here.  1) DEMOCRAT COMPLACENCY: If the DNC and Democrats in general become too complacent because they assume they will unseat Gardener they could definitely wind up surprised in November. I believe Democrat complacency could reduce Democrat turnout in November by several percentage points, and possible swing the election when combined with other factors. It is not that Democrats need to pour substantial resources into Colorado to defeat Gardener, but a well funded, motivated and mobilized Republican base could return Gardener for another term, especially if Democrats nominate an unknown quantity. Which brings us to wildcard #2.  2) DEMOCRAT NOMINEE: The individual Democrats nominate for Senate in Coloradoan 2020 could also alter the vote by several percentage points. For better or worse we live in a society whose politics is heavily predicated on the concept of individual celebrity. Donald Trump is not the cause of this, he is merely the great benefactor of a culture that views celebrity as a form of modern day currency and competency. More well known candidates inherently draw greater attention, creating feedback loops with media and driving larger voter turnout, both for and against. Donald Trumps fame inherently draws a high degree of voter turnout and most voters who vote for Trump will also vote for Cory Gardener. But the same is not inherently true for Democrats. A voter who goes to vote specifically against Trump may not inherently vote for Gardener's Democrat opponent. I believe name recognition will matter this November in Colorado with former Governor Hickenlooper offering the strongest odds against Gardener. 3) ECONOMY/CORONAVIRUS: The obvious wildcard in all of this is the state of the economy in Nov. 2020 and the nature of coronavirus. Barring some sudden and dramatic upward shift in both the economy the trajectory of coronavirus I believe Gardener's preexisting unpopularity in Colorado will make it virtually impossible for him to be reelected. However, if coronavirus miraculously goes away over the summer, we do not have any additional spikes in cases, and the global/national/state economies all ramp back it will not mean Gardener is likely to win reelection, only that those factors will not also be drags upon his incumbency. There is a small, albeit real, chance that coronavirus could cause such a cataclysmic collapse of the global/national/state economies that a third party candidate could manage to ride the crisis into office.
I've been watching the Polls, but I also think that Hickenlooper was a popular Governor, who was able to work across the aisle in CO.
Negative net approval in Colorado for IMPOTUS

Colorado has been trending Democratic in the past few elections. Cory Gardner (R) narrowly won the seat in 2014, but in 2020 he will likely be running against John Hickenlooper (D), the very popular former governor of the state.

- 2018 Colorado elected Jared Polis (D) governor with 53.4% of vote
- Polis replaced incumbent John Hickenlooper due to term limits
- Hickenlooper is the likely Democratic nominee & out-raised current Sen. Cory Gardner (R) in the latest quarter This is a case of incumbent staying power (~85% re-election rate for senate in past several elections) vs momentum of a party. Hickenlooper is a household name in Colorado so, assuming he wins the primary, he will likely be favored in this election.
I am in the don't overthink this camp.  Colorado has been shifting blue.
Gardner can only win in a massive national red wave or a Colorado specific scandal.   Colorado is too blue, and national blue forces will be looking to take that seat.

This is a toss-up, with a R incumbent and a well-liked former governor running for the D. Sources put the R ahead by 5% [1]; D is out raising R, but has less total cash [2]. Calling a slight advantage to the incumbent for now. [1] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Maps/May02.html
[2] https://coloradosun.com/2020/04/16/hickenlooper-gardner-fundraising-first-quarter-senate-race-colorado/
Trump lost bigly to Hillary here in 2016, and Dems will have a solid candidate. No reason to overthink this one.

It looks very likely the election will be between (D) Hickenlooper and (R) Gardner. Given Hickenlooper's popularity in Colorado, his fundraising, and his previous time as governor it is very likely he can overcome Garden's incumbency advantage. Colorado is leaning more and more blue and I think it is likely the democrat wins. Outside sources suggest toss-up or lean Democrat. [1] [2] [3]. [1] https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-election/consensus-2020-senate-forecast
[2] https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-election/sabatos-crystal-ball-2020-ratings
[3] https://electionprojection.com/senate-elections.php

Cory Grdner won in 2014 by less than 50000 votes. Incumbent's from both parties have not fared well in Colorado elections since the 1990s. If Gardner can win a it will be only the 3rd senatorial election won by the incumbent since 2002.

One of these days "Someone Else" will have their day in the sun, and they'll recognize I believed in them all along... Also, legalization leans thinking to the left, in my opinion. I'll review and reconsider later.

Hickenlooper raised a lot of money last quarter and has name recognition from his time as governor.  And Republicans are tied to Trump, even when it's not in their best interest for their prospects for reelection.
Hickenlooper is up 13% according to realpolitics.

“This reelection path for Gardner isn’t impossible, but he needs some things to break his way in order to retain his seat. Hence, it makes more sense to look at Gardner as an underdog,” the Crystal Ball concluded. The forecast noted that Gardner’s 48%-46% victory in 2014 over then-U.S. Sen. Mark Udall came in part from a strong performance in Congressional District 6. Since then, the district has voted in much greater margins for Democrats. The Crystal Ball concluded that Gardner would not likely receive many votes from Democrats in the district this time, “at least not in the necessary volume he’d traditionally need.” https://www.coloradopolitics.com/2020-election/colorado-senate-race-moves-to-leans-democratic/article_1543d100-5418-11ea-b141-33e76d5624cf.html
